head.title: Elegy XII.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 47-49.

lg.l: Are those the haunts where genius loves to dwell?
Those dreary mournful melancholy shades;
You who have trode the doleful mazes tell
What heart corroding anguish here invades.
I thought the Muses lov’d the flow’ry road,
Where joy and pleasure unmolested stray,
Where gentle peace had fix’d her sweet abode,
And mild contentment held eternal sway.
Beneath the shade, in careless ease reclin’d,
I thought the Poets pass’d their jocund hours,
While tides of sweet ideas fill’d each mind,
Like happy souls in bless’d elysian bow’rs.
Let sad experience tell the mournful truth,
How studious vigils are the source of wo,
How thought impairs the rosy bloom of youth,
And makes the tears of heart-felt anguish flow.
There melancholy sits, with lurid eye,
While sad ideas rankle in the soul,
Griev’d disappointment oft demands a sigh,
And doth the thoughts of future joy controul.
I see the sons of jollity and joy
The genial hours in revelry beguile;
No tender feelings can their mirth annoy,
No sad ideas check the dimpling smile.
In vain, I turn the page of antient lore,
To lull the furious Demon of despair;
In vain, divine philosophy explore,
To dissipate this weary load of care.
For pale disease, the sad result of those,
Impairs the pleasures that delight the heart;
Terrific dreams infest my short repose,
And death seems threatning with uplifted dart.
